content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy B{B} to ensure a more consistent payoff over the 75 rounds. Here's why:

1. If my anonymous partner always chooses R (their optimal strategy for beating B), they will get 35$ in each round where I pick B, and I will get 0$. However, I still receive 40$ every time we both pick B, which occurs quite often since the game has 75 rounds.

2. If my anonymous partner sometimes chooses R and other times chooses B (a mixed strategy), then I would expect to gain more by choosing B consistently. This is because if they choose B when I pick R, we both get 40$, but if they choose R when I pick B, they only receive 35$.

3. In the worst-case scenario, my partner also chooses B consistently. In this case, I would earn 40$ in each of the 75 rounds. Although my earnings are lower than the potential 187.5$ (45$ per round) if we both always pick R, I am still receiving a consistent payoff.

4. Since the game is anonymous and there's no way to know the exact strategy of my partner, choosing B ensures that I receive a more stable and higher average payoff than if I were to choose R.

So, based on these considerations, I would choose strategy B{B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, I would continue with my strategy of choosing B{B}. Since both me and my opponent chose B in the previous round, we received a payoff of 40$ each. If I were to change my strategy now and choose R, it could potentially lead to a negative outcome if my opponent continues with their strategy of choosing B. However, since I don't have any information about my opponent's thinking process or future strategies, I would stick with the strategy that has been working so far: B{B}.

In this scenario, I would reconsider my strategy. Since I picked B and my opponent chose R in the previous round, I received a payoff of 35$, while my opponent got nothing. If I were to continue with my strategy of choosing B, there's a high chance that I will keep losing money (0$ or 35$) as long as my opponent sticks with their R strategy.

To maximize my earnings, I would switch my strategy to R{R} for the next round. This way, if my opponent continues to pick R, we will both receive 45$ each round. If my opponent switches their strategy to B, I will still earn more than if I were to continue with B (since they get 0$ when picking R while I receive 35$). However, if I were to switch back to B after my opponent chooses R once, it would be unlikely that I would recover the loss of potential earnings from the first round where I picked B.

So, based on these considerations, I would choose strategy R{R} for the next round.
